title-group.article-title: Investigation of physical properties and structure–property relationship in new poly(azo-sulfone-amide)s

contrib-group.aff: Nanosciences and Catalysis Division, National Centre For Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University Campus, Islamabad, Pakistan

author-notes.corresp: Ayesha Kausar, Nanosciences and Catalysis Division, National Centre For Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University Campus, Islamabad 44000, Pakistan. Email: asheesgreat@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Series of aromatic polyamides containing azo groups have been synthesized by the phosphorylation polycondensation of a new dicarboxylic acid (E)-1-(4-(4-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiocarbamoylaminophenyl-sulfonyl)phenyl)-3-(3-carboxypyridylazo)-thiourea and various diamines. Poly(azo-sulfone-amide)s (PASAs) were characterized using spectroscopic techniques, solubility, molar mass, electrical conductivity, mechanical strength, nonflammability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) studies. PASAs possessed fine solubility in polar solvents and high molar mass 70 × 103–75 × 103 gmol−1. These polyamides showed fibrous structure according to field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). Thermal and nonflammability data indicated that PASAs were fairly stable above 500°C having initial weight loss of around 525–531°C, 10% of gravimetric loss in the range of 542–563°C, own high glass transition temperature 257–267°C and limiting oxygen index (LOI) values (35–47%). The polymers also demonstrated higher tensile strength (61.10–74.29 MPa) and elongation at break (1.49–1.57). FESEM images displayed fibrous morphology of the PASAs. Moreover, polyamides showed superior electrical conductivity (1.45–1.92 S cm−1). Fine balance of the properties render the new PASAs potential engineering plastics for a number of aerospace relevance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Thermally stable polymers have received extensive significance owing to their escalating demands for high-temperature materials as a fine replacement for metals/ceramics in the automotive, aerospace and microelectronics industries. Aromatic polyamides are certainly one of the most successful classes of high-performance polymers owing to their thermal stability, low flammability, chemical resistance and excellent mechanical properties.1–3 They encounter processing difficulties due to the limited solubility in organic solvents and high glass transition (Tg) or melting temperature (Tm) primarily because of strong interchain attractive forces such as hydrogen bonding between amide groups, which enhance effective molecular packing and chain rigidity.4 It is, therefore, of scrupulous interest to develop these materials with structural modifications to maintain the rod-like characteristics and thermal stability along with good processability. In this regard, knowledge and comprehension of the relationship between the chemical structure and properties of polymers is an important prerequisite for the development of new improved materials. Recent research has been focused on the synthesis of rigid-rod polyamides with increased number of aromatic rings that enhance the rigidity of the polymer backbone due to strong interactions of polarizable π-electrons. Rigid-rod polymers demonstrate exceptional thermal stability, mechanical strength, morphological properties, and so on. Generally, the introduction of flexible linkages (–O–, –SO2–, etc.) into the aromatic main chain enhances the chain suppleness and offer better solubility, but it decreases thermal transitions and stability.5–7 On the other hand, the bulky pendent groups are capable of providing beneficial consequences through chain separation effects via the weakening of hydrogen bonding, and lowering of chain packing with a gain of free volume. At the same time, bulky side groups also give rise to restricted molecular mobility, so that the overall observable effect is a rising of the glass-transition temperature and an improvement in solubility.8–12 Another approach employed to increase the solubility of polyamide is incorporation of the nonlinear moieties such as bulky noncoplanar groups in the polymer backbone.13

Among the several categories of thermally stable polymers, azo polyamides are of considerable significance. Azo-containing polymers are the macromolecules with azo groups in the main chain or side chain. Polymers with azo-benzene moiety have good stability and usually show high glass transition temperature. Moreover, the azo group in a polymer backbone increases the chain stiffness and imparts color to the polymer and, therefore, has potential applications as high-modulus fibers/films and high-grade pigments of good stability toward light and organic solvents. Consequently, the synthesis, characterization and film/fiber studies of several aromatic and semiaromatic azo polyamides have been reported.14–19 Thus, introducing azo-benzene linkage in the polymeric main chain can improve thermal stability and allow broad application as engineering plastics.20,21 In the present study, some new thermally stable and flame-retardant polyamides containing sulfoxide and azo-benzene moieties in the main chain have been prepared by the direct polycondensation. A novel dicarboxylic acid (E)-1-(4-(4-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiocarbamoylaminophenyl-sulfonyl)phenyl)-3-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiourea (CPATCAPST) was condensed with various diamines (1,4-phenylene diamine, 1,5-diamino naphthalene and 4,4'-oxydianniline) using triphenyl phosphate, pyridine and lithium chloride in N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP). Furthermore, the solubility, molar mass, morphology, electrical conductivity, mechanical strength, thermal stability and flame retardance of new poly(azo-sulfone-amide)s (PASAs) were studied via suitable techniques. Thermal stability and limiting oxygen index (LOI) results showed that the incorporation of sulfone, thiourea and azo-pyridine moieties in the main chain dramatically increased the flame retardant property of the polymer. The PASAs had high molar mass and were soluble in common organic solvents. Moreover, the polymers were found to be electrically conducting and possess fine mechanical strength according to the tensile tests. All these properties make these polymers quite attractive for practical applications such as processable high-performance engineering materials.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: 2-Aminopyridine-3-carboxylic acid (98%), 1,4-phenylene diamine (PDA) (99%), 1,5-diamino naphthalene (DAN) (97%), 4,4'-oxydianniline (ODA) (97%), 4-(4-aminophenylsulfonyl)benzenamine (APSBA) (97%), triphenyl phosphite (TPP) (97%), lithium chloride (LiCl) (≥99%), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) (99%), xylene (99%), pyridine (99.8%) and toluene (99.8%) were provided by Aldrich (St. Louis, Missouri, USA). Ammonium thiocyanate (98%), dimethylformamide (DMF) (99%) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) (99.5%) were supplied by Fluka (Biocen GmbH, Duesseldorf, Germany). NMP (99%), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (99%) and chloroform (99%) were procured from Merck (Nottingham, UK).

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were scanned at room temperature using BRUKER Spectrometer, Karlsruhe, Germany (300.13 MHz for 1H and at 75.47 MHz for 13C NMR) in deutrated DMSO.Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded using Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer, Model No. FTSW 300 MX, manufactured by BIO-RAD, California, USA (4 cm–1 resolution). Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer was used for the elemental analysis. The number and weight-average molecular weight (Mn and Mw) were calculated through Gel-permeation chromatography (GPC) using DMF as an eluent and refractive index (RI) detector. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) of freeze-fractured samples was performed using JSM5910, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan. Thermal stability of the polymers was verified by Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e thermo gravimetric analyzer using 1–5 mg of the sample in Al2O3 crucible at a heating rate of 10°C/min. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed by Mettler Toledo DSC 822e differential scanning calorimeter taking 5–10 mg of samples in aluminum pans and heating at a rate of 10°C/min. Stanton Redcroft FTA Flammability Unit (nitrogen gas, oxygen gas and precision pressure regulator systems) was used to find out the LOI of PASAs. LOI values were determined according to ASTM D 2863 that is a method to determine the minimum concentration of oxygen in an oxygen/nitrogen mixture that will support a flaming burn in a specimen. X-Ray diffractometer (3040/60 X’pert PRO) with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 30 mA) was used to obtain x-ray diffractogram of polymers at room temperature. Electrical conductivity of thin films was measured using a Keithley 614 electrometer and the four-probe method. Stress–strain response of the samples was obtained on Universal Testing Machine INSTRON 4206, according to the ASTM 638 method. A crosshead speed of 100 mm/min was used during the test.

sec.title: Monomer synthesis
sec.p: The monomer was obtained via the three-step procedure, starting from the preparation of bisthiourea namely 1-(4-thiocarbamoylaminophenylsulfonylphenyl)thiourea (TCAPST) from its corresponding diamine 4-(4-aminophenylsulfonyl)benzenamine. Second step was the diazotization reaction of 2-aminopyridine-3-carboxylic acid and in the final step the coupling reaction of diazonium salt with TCAPST in the presence of an alkali, which resulted in the monomer (E)-1-(4-(4-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiocarbamoylaminophenylsulfonyl)phenyl)-3-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiourea (CPATCAPST).

Synthesis of 1-(4-thiocarbamoylaminophenylsulfonylphenyl)thiourea (TCAPST). 4-(4-aminophenylsulfonyl)benzenamine (0.2 mol), conc. HCl (16 mL), ammonium thiocyanate (0.2 mol) and deaerated water (120 mL) were mixed and heated in a porcelain dish (2 h) on a steam bath. The mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. Afterwards, the mixture was gradually evaporated to dryness for 6–7 h. The product obtained was boiled with charcoal in ethanol, filtered and cooled. 1-(4-thiocarbamoylaminophenyl-sulfonylphenyl)thiourea was recrystallized from ethanol and dried under vacuum at 90°C (36 h).22,23 Elemental analysis for C14H14N4O2S3: calculated = % C 45.88, % H 3.85, % N 15.29; found = %C 43.32, %H 3.69, %N 14.49. FTIR (KBr): 3365 cm−1, 3234 cm−1 (N–H stretch), 3019 cm−1 (aromatic C–H stretch), 2945 (aliphatic C–H stretch), 1599 cm−1 (N–H bend), 1413 cm−1 (C–N stretch), 1301 and 1157 (S=O stretch), 1123 cm−1 (C=S stretch). 1H NMR (300.13 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ, ppm): 4.38 (s, 4H, Ha), 9.32 (s, 2H, Hb), 6.65 (d, 4H, Hc), 7.71 (d, 4H, Hd). 13C NMR (75.47 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ, ppm): thiocarbonyl C=S 175.1 (C1), 142.4 (C2), 125.3 (C3), 128.1 (C4), 139.9 (C5).

Diazotization. 0.04 mol of 2-aminopyridine-3-carboxylic acid was first added to concentrated hydrochloric acid (10 mL) and then dissolved in distilled water (50 mL). The mixture was placed in a freezing bath to cool to −10°C, ensuring brown precipitate. To the above suspension, 0.04 mol of sodium nitrite solution (20 mL) was carefully added drop wise with constant stirring. After the complete addition, the mixture was further allowed to stir for 1 h at −10°C to evade the decomposition of diazonium salt. Finally, the excess of nitrite was removed by the addition of urea (2 g) with stirring for 20 min, resulting in a brownish yellow diazonium salt solution.

Synthesis of (E)-1-(4-(4-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiocarbamoylaminophenyl-sulfonyl)phenyl)-3-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiourea (CPATCAPST). 0.02 mol of TCAPST was dissolved in sodium hydroxide (10%) and then the diazonium salt solution obtained (section on Diazotization) was added drop wise keeping the reaction temperature below −10°C. The mixture was further stirred for 3 h and acidified with dilute HCl (10%). The resulting precipitate was filtered and washed with hot water and then with HCl (3%). The precipitate was again dissolved in sodium hydroxide (3%) followed by re-precipitation in HCl.24 The monomer obtained was dried under vacuum at 70°C for 36 h. Elemental analysis for C26H20N10O6S3: calculated = % C 46.98, % H 3.03, % N 21.07; found = % C 44.99, % H 2.98, % N 19.34. FTIR (KBr) (Figure 1): 3483 cm−1 (acid –OH), 3333 and 1598 cm−1 (secondary amine N–H stretch and bend), 3079 cm−1 (aromatic C–H stretch), 1780 cm−1 (acid C=O), 1413 cm−1 (–N=N– stretch), 1307 and 1161 (S=O stretch), 1128 cm−1 (C=S stretch), 832 cm−1 (C–S stretching). 1H NMR (300.13 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ, ppm) given in Figure 2: 11.10 (s, 2H, Ha), 8.23 (d, 2H, Hb), 7.69 (t, 2H, Hc), 8.68 (d, 2H, Hd), 8.92 (s, 2H, He), 9.83 (s, 2H, Hf), 6.94 (d, 4H, Hg), 7.36 (d, 4H, Hh). 13C NMR (75.47 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ, ppm) presented in Figure 3: acid C=O 169.6 (C1), 119.7 (C2), 137.1 (C3), 121.3 (C4), 152.4 (C5), 172.2 (C6), thiocarbonyl C=S 183.4 (C7), 142.3 (C8), 127.6 (C9), 128.8 (C10), 138.2 (C11).

caption.p: 1H NMR: proton nuclear magnetic resonance; CPATCAPST: (E)-1-(4-(4-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiocarbamoylaminophenyl-sulfonyl)phenyl)-3-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiourea.

sec.title: Synthesis of PASAs
sec.p: PASAs were synthesized by the phosphorylation polyamidation of CPATCAPST with various diamines as shown in Figure 7. A typical example for the preparation of polyamides is given. PASA 1 was synthesized from CPATCAPST and PDA. A mixture of 0.66 g (0.001 mol) of CPATCAPST, 0.10 g (0.001 mol) of PDA, 0.3 g of LiCl, 0.6 mL of TPP, 0.5 mL of pyridine, and 4 mL of NMP were heated and stirred at 120°C for 6 h under nitrogen (N2). The resulting reaction mixture was poured into 300 mL of methanol. The stringy orange polymer was washed thoroughly with methanol and hot water, collected by filtration and dried under vacuum at 100°C overnight. FTIR (KBr) (Figure 4): 3329 and 1593 cm−1 (secondary amine N–H stretch and bend), 3017 cm−1 (aromatic C–H stretch), 1688 cm−1 (amide C=O), 1415 cm−1 (–N=N– stretch), 1313 and 1166 (S=O stretch), 1127 cm−1 (C=S stretch), 832 cm−1 (C–S stretching).1H NMR (300.13 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ, ppm) given in Figure 5: PASA 1 displayed chemical shifts due to N–Hs around 8.91 and 9.85 ppm. The pyridine unit coming from CPATCAPST monomer exhibited doublets at 8.52 and 8.96 and triplet at 7.99 ppm. Moreover, doublets around 6.69 and 7.43 ppm appeared because of phenyl ring protons of the dicarboxylic unit. The phenylene ring protons of PDA unit showed doublets of about 6.54 and 7.21 ppm. PASA 2 (FTIR, KBr, cm−1): 3317, 1596 cm−1 (secondary amine N–H), 3021 (aromatic C–H stretch), 1689 (amide C=O), 1414 (–N=N– stretch), 1314, 1167 (S=O stretch), 1125 (C=S stretch), 831 (C–S stretching). PASA 2 (1H NMR, DMSO-d6, δ, ppm): 8.88 (s), 9.84 (s) (N–Hs chemical shifts), 8.45 (d), 8.93 (d), 7.95 (t) (pyridine unit), 6.64 (d), 7.40 (d) (phenyl ring protons of CPATCAPST unit), 6.52 (d), 7.11 (t), 7.23 (d) (naphthalene unit). PASA 3 (FTIR, KBr, cm−1): 3299, 1597 (secondary amine N–H), 3011 (aromatic C–H stretch), 1691 (amide C=O), 1414 (–N=N– stretch), 1242 (–O– stretch), 1313, 1167 (S=O stretch), 1124 (C=S stretch), 829 (C–S stretching). PASA 3 (1H NMR, DMSO-d6, δ, ppm): 8.82 (s), 9.83 (s) (N–Hs chemical shifts), 8.43 (d), 8.91 (d), 7.85 (t) (pyridine unit), 6.64 (d), 7.36 (d) (protons of CPATCAPST unit), 6.34 (d), 6.79 (d), 7.04 (d), 7.56 (d) (ODA unit).

caption.p: 1H NMR: proton nuclear magnetic resonance; PASA: poly(azo-sulfone-amide)s.

sec.title: Film casting
sec.p: The desired amount of polymer was dissolved in DMAc by continuous stirring for 24 h. This resulted in a homogeneous, transparent and viscous solution. A thin transparent layer of solution was spread on a Teflon mold and heated at 80°C for 12 h to obtain films. The films obtained were dried under vacuum at 80°C overnight.

sec.title: Synthesis of dicarboxylic acid and polyamides
sec.p: In this article, we have reported the preparation, properties and structure–property relationship of new azo polyamides obtained from (E)-1-(4-(4-(3-carboxypyridylazo)thiocarbamoyl-aminophenylsulfonyl)phenyl)-3-(3-carboxypyridylazo)-thiourea containing sulfone, azo, pyridine and thiourea moieties. CPATCAPST monomer was synthesized as shown in Figure 6, using 1-(4-thiocarbamoylaminophenylsulfonyl-phenyl)thiourea and diazonium salt solution. Polyamides PASA 1–3 were then prepared by the direct polycondensation of dicarboxylic acid CPATCAPST with aromatic diamines using triphenyl phosphite and pyridine as condensing agents (Figure 7). All the polymerization proceeded in homogeneous solutions and yields of the polymers were quantitative. The compounds obtained were characterized by elemental analysis, FTIR, 1H and 13C NMR and the results were in agreement with the proposed structures. According to FTIR, hydroxyl and carbonyl groups of carboxylic acid showed stretching vibration at 3483 and 1780 cm−1, respectively, in the monomeric compound. These bands disappeared in the case of PASAs, however stretching vibration due to amide C=O was observable at 1688 cm−1. FTIR spectrum of the monomer and polymers also showed stretching vibration at 1413–1415 cm−1, indicating –N=N– group. Generally, it is complex to identify –N=N– stretching frequency because of the influence of aromatic –CH=CH– ring vibration, although an intense band was easily perceived in these polymers. 1H NMR of PASA 1 exhibited the loss of chemical shift at 11.10 ppm (observed for monomer), verifying the polycondenstion. The C=S and C–S stretching frequencies were observed around 1127 and 832 cm−1 for the monomers as well as polymers. The ensuing PASAs had fairly high molar mass up to 75 × 103 gmol−1. The polyamides displayed a fibrous structure according to FESEM (Figure 8), indicating good tensile strength. Thermal and electrical data authenticated that the structural modification was a valid approach to obtain polymers with superior thermal stability, Tg, along with electrical conductivity without affecting their solvent miscibility.

sec.title: Organosolubility
sec.p: The solubility of new polymers was evaluated in a wide range of solvents through visual examination. The solubility was studied at room temperature and heating up to the solvent’s boiling temperature for the samples that remained insoluble at room temperature. For this purpose, approximately 10 mg of polymer was added under vigorous stirring to 1 mL of selected solvents. The results are summarized in Table 1. Usually, aromatic polyazo or heteroaromatic polymers possess low solubility in organic solvents due to their rigid backbone structure. aSolubility is indicated as follows: ++: soluble at room temperature; +h: soluble on heating; +–: partially soluble on heating; –: insoluble.

sec.p: PASA 3 dissolved in DMF at room temperature, PASA 2 was soluble on heating while PASA 1 was just partially soluble on heating. The good solubility of PASA 3 can be attributed to the combine effect of –O– and S=O linkages in the backbone. On the other hand, DMAc and DMSO proved to be good solvents for PASA 1–3 at room temperature (dissolved without heating). In general, sulfone substituents in stiff-chain polymers are known to increase solubility because of their capacity to disrupt the chain packing. Thus, the introduction of sulfone moieties in the azo polymers determined their fine solubility in DMAc and DMSO. Despite the fact that a substantial ether segment was present in the repeat unit of PASA 3, common solvents such as THF/chloroform did not dissolve the polymer, at room temperature or even at elevated temperature. Classical solvents for polyamides such as m-cresol and sulfuric acid also did not dissolve the present polymers at ambient temperature. Furthermore, notorious H-bond-breaking organic solvents such as NMP dissolved the polymers after heating for few hours. At elevated temperature, that is above 80°C, PASA 1–3 dissipated in NMP, yielding viscous solutions, and upon cooling, clear thermoreversible gel was formed. On the whole, the solubility was found to be superior relative to the previous azo-based polymers.25

sec.title: Molecular weight
sec.p: Gel-permeation chromatographic measurement was carried out for the determination of molecular weight of polymers (Table 2) and found to be in the range of 70 × 103–75 × 103 gmol−1. A relationship between the molar mass of the polymer and its structure can be observed from this study. This showed that a polymer derived from dicarboxylic acid and 1,4-phenylene diamine by the phosphorylation method yielded a higher Mw of 75 × 103, though it decreased for the polymer derived from 4,4'-oxydianniline (70 × 103). Accordingly, PASA 1 with –CPATCAPST–PDA– architecture displayed higher molar mass due to rigidity and symmetric alignment of the polymer chains. Introduction of ether linkages in PASA 3, on the other hand, induced looser chain packing affecting the molecular weight of the polymer. However, the Mw values were considerably higher than the previous azo-based polymers.26

sec.title: Thermal stability
sec.p: Thermal characteristics of the present polyamides were investigated using thermogravimetric analysis and DSC at heating rates of 10°C/min. Generally, azo polymers are recognized for their high thermal stability.26–28 TGA results, together with DSC data for PASA1–3 are summarized in Table 3 and Figure 9. For PASA 1, initial decomposition set around 531°C, 10% gravimetric loss was at 563°C and the decomposition extended up to 668°C. For PASA 2 To was about 529°C, T10 was 559°C and Tmax around 654°C. sec.p: The trend showed that PASA 1 derived from p-phenylene-based diamine was more stable than the polymers derived from naphthalene/ether containing monomers. PASA 3 was, so, found to exhibit comparatively lower heat stability as To 525°C, T10 542°C and Tmax 599°C. Char yield of PASA 1 and 2 (48–53% at 700°C) also indicated their high stability. The overall higher stability of polymers could be attributed to the incorporation of preformed azo, and heteroaromatic pyridine units in the polymer backbone. TGA curves showed single stage of weight loss well above 500°C. The single-stage weight loss behavior is also a sign of high thermal stability. It was possibly due to the cleavage of azo group together with the bond between N and C of amide unit. According to DSC reports, PASAs showed Tgs in the range of 257–267°C and the thermograms obtained are displayed in Figure 10. Higher glass transition of PASAs was recorded without any softening or melting transition. PASA 1 led to a higher Tg of 267°C due to the intense chain rigidity and intermolecular hydrogen bonding of N–H with amide/thio-carbonyl, thus lowering the intersegmental activity. A decrease in Tg (257°C) was noticed in PASA 3 relative to PASAs 1 and 2. This was probably due to the disorder induced in the regularly arranged structural segments in heteroaromatic polyazos, thus enhancing the molecular mobility. The flame retardance of the PASAs was evaluated by measuring their LOI values and the polymer showed good LOI data (Table 3). Moreover, higher char yield of the polymers around 700°C also indicated intrinsic fire resistance. Generally, materials exhibiting LOI values above 30 are capable of showing self-extinguishing behavior and are considered as flame retardant. The experimental results suggested that PASA 1 with p-linkage in the backbone have higher flame retardancy. Hence, the introduction of sulfur-containing groups (S=O and C=S) was found to increase the nonflammability of the polymers without reducing their thermal stability. The polyazos were found to be sufficiently nonflammable relative to the previous polymers29 and exhibited higher LOI value for PASA 1, as in the case of their thermal stability (Table 3). The results showed that the presence of sulfone, thiourea and azobenzene moieties in the main chain dramatically increased the flame-retardant property of these polymers.

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p: Wide-angle x-ray diffractograms of PASA 1–3 showed a prominent reflection 2θ = 17–21 (Figure 11), indicative of some degree of crystallinity in the material. These heteroaromatic rigid-rod azo polymers were predictable to reveal crystalline pattern due to better chain packing of macromolecular spine. Intermolecular interaction of amide carbonyl/thio-carbonyl with N–H was also believed to be responsible for close polymer packing.

sec.title: Conductivity studies
sec.p: In this research, the presence of azo and pyridine moieties was found to significantly increase the conductivity of PASAs as shown in Table 4. Reasonably high electrical conductivity of around 1.45–1.92 S cm−1 was observed for PASAs. The conductivity of PASA 1 was found to be 1.92 S cm−1, even as it slowly decreased up to 1.45 S cm−1 induced by structural variations. When comparing the electrical conductivity of new polymers, the highest value was observed for one having better alignment of the polymer chains. That means, the conductivity properties were also considerably affected by the backbone rigidity. Conductivity of new materials was also found to be superior relative to that of previous polyazos.30

sec.title: Tensile strength
sec.p: The polyamide films were dried and their mechanical properties were investigated by standard tensile tests (Table 5). The tensile plots are depicted in Figure 12. The initial modulus of PASA 1 sample at room temperature was found to be 237 MPa, and 223 MPa for PASA 2. The tensile strength was 74.29 and 66.89 for PASA 1 and PASA 2, respectively. In comparison with previous polymers, these values initially seemed to be rather high.26 ODA-based PASAs, however, showed lower values in tensile strength (61.10 MPa) and initial modulus (211 MPa). Higher value of the elongation at break was also observed for PASA 1 (1.57) relative to that of PASA 2 (1.52) and PASA 3 (1.49). Toughness of the materials, evaluated by integrating area under the stress–strain curve, was in the range of 54.32–76.20 J/m3.16,26,31

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this attempt, a novel monomer CPATCAPST was prepared through the coupling reaction of diazonium chloride with a bisthiourea compound. PASAs were afterwards developed by the phosphorylation polycondensation of monomer with aromatic diamines. Thermal, mechanical and conductivity performance of the polymers obtained was tuned via structural modification. The enhancement of the physical properties (thermal stability, nonflammability, glass transition temperature, mechanical strength, molar mass, electrical conductivity, etc.) of polymeric materials while maintaining their processability was the main aim. The azo and pyridine moieties introduced in the backbone render PASAs thermally and mechanically stable as well as electrically conducting. The heteroaromatic PASA 1 obtained by p-phenylene diamine exhibited higher Tg, thermal and electrically conducting properties compared with other PASAs owing to rigid aromatic structure. Fine flame-retardant characteristics were also evident from the LOI measurement. FESEM images depicted the fiber-like morphology of novel polyamides. New processable and high-performance engineering plastics, attractive for aerospace applications, can be fabricated from PASAs.
